Inorganic Materials and Catalysis Division, CSIR-Central Salt and Marine Chemicals Research Institute Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR) GB Marg Bhavnagar 364 002 India In this paper, we demonstrate the preparation of ketals from biomass-based carbonyl compounds and polyols. Our emphasis is on levulinate-based ketals using ethyl levulinate (EL) with ethylene glycol (EG) or glycerol (Gly) as polyols. Among the catalysts screened, Na-β zeolite resulted in 99% conversion of EL with 100% selectivity for the corresponding ketal within 1 h, when used in conjunction with azeotropic distillation in cyclohexane medium. Using Gly-as the polyol, a similar yield and selectivity was obtained, albeit after a longer reaction time (4 h). We have explored the reaction scope by using a multitude of biomass-based ketones and polyols as reactants, which showed excellent selectivity for the ketals. Slight deactivation of the catalyst was observed after reaction, owing to the deposition of organic carbon on the catalyst, which was identified using analytical tools. The deactivated catalyst was regenerated on calcination. This strategy was successfully demonstrated for ketal preparation using crude glycerol with EL. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Levulinates Ketals Heterogeneous catalyst Selectivity β-zeolite 1 Introduction Organic compounds such as fuels, polymers, and chemicals are largely produced from fossil resources like petroleum, coal, and natural gas. Nowadays, an increase in population coupled to technological developments, are responsible for an accelerated depletion of the fossil fuel sources. Moreover, fossil fuels are also implicated in global warming due to enhanced carbon emissions on their consumption. Biomass is an alternative renewable source for making fuels, polymers, and chemical intermediates. The advantages of using biomass sources are: enhancing the rural economy, maintaining greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in the atmosphere, and increase in the opportunities in science and technology [1–3]. Generally, the major contents of biomass are plant cell wall (lignocellulose) and plant seeds (triglycerides). The primary platform chemicals from lignocellulose/triglyceride biomass are sugars, polyols, furans, carboxylic acids, and phenolics which are derived from both biological and chemical transformations [4–14]. The catalytic transformation of bio-based platform molecules to value added products (existing and emerging), leads to a huge impact especially for the next generation and is creating an interest to the researchers, because of its sustainability. In the past few years, many valuable chemicals have been reported using this strategy, some of which are mentioned below. 1 Preparation of γ-valerolactone from hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) using formic acid as the hydrogen source. Both the reactants are obtained from acid hydrolysis of cellulose [15,16]. 2 Aldol condensation between biomass-based carbonyl compounds (furfural, 5-hydroxymethyl furfural, LA and 2-hexanone) to generate fuel and polymer intermediates [17–19]. 3 Preparation of bisphenols (plasticizer) from the condensation of cellulose derived ketones (LA and 2,3-pentanedione) with lignin-based phenolics [20,21]. 4 Preparation of high quality diesel from cellulose derived 2-methylfuran (derived from furfural hydrogenation) with angelica lactone (dehydration of LA) by CC bond formation followed by hydrogenation/hydrodeoxygenation [22]. 5 Preparation of acetals and ketals from carbohydrate derived furfural and levulinic esters with lignocellulose/triglyceride derived polyols [23]. The production of ketals is industrially relevant due to their huge demand. Especially, levulinic acid (and ester)-based ketals are a broad family of chemicals having bio-based compositions with many industrial applications. The levulinic-ketal based products have good thermal stability, low toxicity, broad compatibility due to high oxygen content, and high boiling point. The ketals have a broad solubility range enabling their use as cleaning solvents or coupling agents in liquid formulations. Extending the reaction chemistry of levulinic ester-ketal by employing trans-esterification reaction with higher alcohols ends with long chain trans-esterified product which may act as plasticizers, with the potential to replace major phthalate-based plasticizers presently in use. This chemistry can further be extended to the synthesis of binders, surfactants, thermosets, and thermoplastic polymers (Scheme 1 ) [24,25]. The bio-based ketals are mainly prepared from levulinic esters with glycerol or ethylene glycol. These reactants can be easily sourced from biomass; LA and glycerol are being produced at industrial scale. United States Department of Energy (USDoE) identified LA as a potential carbohydrate derived functional building block; it is a keto carboxylic acid that plays an important role in the area of catalytic organic transformation into valuable chemicals by reacting with other biomass-based molecules [19,26–29]. LA is easily obtained from the abundant lignocellulosic biomass by the acid catalysed dehydration followed by subsequent hydration using various homo/heterogeneous catalysts [30–35]. The other reactant for the synthesis of bio-based ketals are polyols; mainly glycerol which is a by-product of biodiesel and is generally obtained from plant and animal sources in the form of triglycerides. Triglycerides upon trans-esterification converts to glycerol and fatty ester (Biodiesel) [36,37]. Crude glycerol is available in huge quantities in the world as many countries have started biodiesel production. The utility of glycerol is related to the presence of hydroxyl moiety that can participate in diverse reactions to form a variety of useful products [38,39]. Another polyol, having a large scope for ketal preparation is ethylene glycol (EG). Currently it is prepared from petrochemical-derived ethylene via the intermediate ethylene oxide. The global annual production of EG is experiencing a tremendous growth due to the rising demand of its polymers (poly ethylene). Recently some research groups reported alternative and sustainable approach for the preparation of EG including a one-pot conversion of biomass sugars using bifunctional catalysts with 60–75% yield of EG via hydrogenolysis (CC bond disconnection) [40–43]. The biomass route for the synthesis of EG would greatly decrease the dependence on petroleum resources for EG production. Despite huge applicability of bio-based ketals, limited reports for their preparation are available in the literature. Segetis (Now GF Biochemicals) disclosed the preparation of levulinic ester-based ketals from levulinic esters with diol/triols using sulphuric acid as the catalyst [24]. Amarasekara and Hawkins reported the preparation of levulinic acid-glycerol ketal-ester oligomers from the reaction of LA with glycerol using acid catalysts such as p-toluenesulfonic acid (p-TsOH), and 1-(1-propylsulfonic)−3-methylimidazolium chloride (PSMIMCl) [44]. In the above mentioned reports, homogeneous catalysts have been used which are difficult to separate from the product mixture and pollute the environment while disposing. Some of these catalysts are expensive and synthesis/purification of ionic liquids necessitates huge chemical usage. Furthermore, the homogeneous acid catalyst needs to be neutralised with large amount of bases after reaction which demands additional energy and chemical input. To overcome these drawbacks, we endeavoured to introduce acidic heterogeneous catalysts for the synthesis of bio-based ketals. In this article, we discussed the screening of various solid acid catalysts and systematic optimization of the reaction parameters in presence of selected catalyst to achieve the maximum yield and selectivity for the desired ketals. The by-product of this reaction is water, which causes a loss in the catalytic activity, entailing its continuous removal during the reaction by azeotropic distillation with the help of Dean-Stark method (apparatus) in cyclohexane. Several biomass-based ketones and polyols were screened including LA, levulinic esters (methyl, ethyl, and butyl), 2-octanone, 5-nonanone, cyclohexanone; and polyols like ethylene glycol, glycerol, 1,2-propanediol, 1,3-propanediol, 1,4-butanediol for their conversion to the corresponding ketals in order to broaden the scope of our reaction [39,45–47]. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The chemicals used levulinic acid (98%), ethyl levulinate (98%), methyl levulinate (≥ 98%), butyl levulinate (98%), ethylene glycol (99%), 5-nonanone (98%), 2-octanone (≥ 98%), octanal (> 99%), glycerol (> 99), 1,2-propanediol (99%), 1,3-propanediol (98%), 1,6-hexanediol (99%), Montmorillonite, and Amberlyst-15 were procured from Sigma-Aldrich. LR grade of cyclohexane, cyclohexanone, 1,4-butanediol, Neutral Alumina, Magnesium Oxide (MgO), and metal salts were purchased from local vendors in India. The zeolites used in this work, i.e., Na-β (Si/Al-25), Na-Y (Si/Al-3), and Na-ZSM-5 (Si/Al-25) were purchased from Zeochem, Switzerland. 2.2 Preparation of H-form β-zeolite The commercial zeolite such as β-form (Si/Al-25) is in the sodium form. This zeolite was used as such for the reaction and also was further transformed into NH4 + form by ion exchange with aqueous NH4Cl solution at 90 °C for 1 h followed by thorough washing. The H+ form was obtained by calcination of NH4 + form of zeolite at 550 °C for 3 h [48]. 2.3 Catalyst characterization PXRD measurements were carried out in a Philips X'Pert MPD system using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The operating voltage and current were 40 kV and 30 mA, respectively. A step size of 0.04° with a step time of 2 s was used for data collection. The data were processed using the Philips X'Pert (version 2.2e) software. Identification of the crystalline phases was made in comparison with the JCPDS files. Fourier transformed-infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded in a Perkin-Elmer GX-FTIR instrument, using KBr pellets between 400 and 4000 cm−1 with an accumulation of 20 scans and 4 cm−1 resolution. The acidity of the materials used for the reaction were analysed through pyridine adsorption and monitored using Fourier-transformed infra-red (Py-FTIR) spectroscopic technique. For py-FTIR analysis, the samples were initially oven-dried at 100 °C for 3 h. To the oven dried sample (50 mg), 0.1 ml of pyridine was admixed directly. To remove the physisorbed pyridine present in the sample, the samples were dried in an oven at 120 °C for 1 h. The samples were cooled to room temperature and the spectra were recorded with 15 scans during the accumulation of each spectrum. The acidity of catalysts was analyzed by NH3-TPD desorption on a Micromeritics Autochem II Chemisorption analyzer. Initially, the samples were activated at 150 °C under a He flow to remove physisorbed H2O molecules and ammonia gas was passed at 100 °C for 30 min. After NH3 adsorption on the zeolites, the temperature was raised from 100 to 700 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 and held for 1 h to desorb the chemisorbed ammonia, TCD detector was employed for the detection of ammonia. Acidity of the materials quantitatively calculated from the peak area obtained. The elemental analysis was carried out using Elementar, Vario Micro Cube CHNS analyser with combustion range 1150 °C in presence of He as the carrier gas. The gases from the degraded samples were confirmed by using ADS resin column with a TCD detector. Specific surface area and pore size of the samples were measured by nitrogen adsorption at −196 °C using a sorptometer (ASAP-2020, Micromeritics). The samples were degassed under vacuum at 150 °C for 3 h prior to measurements in order to expel the physisorbed water molecules. The BET specific surface area was calculated by using the standard Brunauer, Emmett and Teller (BET) method on the basis of the adsorption data. Pore volume and micropore area were also determined. The micropore volume and micropore surface area for the catalyst samples were measured using the t-plot method. The electron microscopic study was done with JSM-7100F scanning electron microscope. The samples were coated with gold before analysis to avoid charging effects during imaging. An accelerating voltage of 15 kV and a working distance of 10 mm, with magnification values in-between 5000x and 20,000x were used for imaging. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were obtained with JEOL JEM-2100 at an acceleration voltage of 300 kV using carbon coated 300 mesh copper grid. The samples were ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol for 5 min and deposited onto carbon film using capillary followed by air-drying for 30 min. Solid-state NMR spectra were acquired on Bruker Avance II 500 MHz spectrometer equipped with a double-resonance CP-MAS probe. The 27Al MAS spectra were recorded at a spinning frequency of 8 KHz with 1024 scans using AlCl3•6H2O as reference and chemical shift range 200 to −220 δ ppm. The 29Si MAS spectra were recorded at a spinning frequency of 8 KHz with 2048 scans using tetramethylsilane (TMS) as reference in the chemical shift range of 150 to −200 δ ppm. 2.4 Preparation of ketals from ethyl levulinate with polyols In a typical reaction, a mixture of ethyl levulinate (1 g, 6.94 mmol), polyol (1–2 mole ratio w.r.t carbonyl compounds), 10 wt% of β-zeolite catalyst w.r.t. EL (100 mg), and cyclohexane (5 mL) were taken in a 20 mL reaction tube. The reaction was carried out in METLER TOLEDO Easy Max 102 glass reactor with the help of Dean-Stark setup at 120 °C (for ethylene glycol) or 140 °C (for glycerol) at 1000 rpm for 1 h (for ethylene glycol) or 4 h (for glycerol). After the reaction, the solid catalyst was separated from product mixture by centrifugation and the supernatant liquid was rotatory evaporated to remove the cyclohexane solvent. The obtained liquid products were characterized by 13C NMR. Conversion of reactants and yield of products were analysed by Varian 450 gas chromatograph (GC) with a flame ionization detector (FID). The conditions for gas chromatography were as follows: ZB-5MS column, 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm; carrier gas: nitrogen; injection temperature, 250 °C; detector temperature, 350 °C; oven temperature, 80 °C to 220 °C at a programmed heating rate of 20 °C/min and 5 min hold at 220 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst screening for preparation of EL-EG ketal The ketal formation was initially investigated with ethyl levulinate (EL) as the ketonic reactant because it can easily be prepared from C-5 and C-6 sugars in high yields [49–52]. Ethylene glycol (EG) was chosen as the polyol reactant. In presence of these two reactants, the ketal obtained is ethyl 3-(2-methyl-1,3-dioxolan-2-yl)propanoate (subsequently referred to as EL-EG ketal), which is similar to fructone (ethyl-2-methyl-1,3-dioxolane-2-acetate), a flavouring agent with apple-like smell. Fructone has been widely used in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, detergents, and lacquer. Fructone can be synthesized by the acetalization reaction of ethyl acetoacetate with EG using acid catalysts. Many catalysts were reported for this reaction such as sulphuric acid, p-toluenesulfonic acid, heteropoly acids (HPA), and ionic liquids [53,54]. The present report for the synthesis of EL-EG ketal is sustainable and this molecule is a potential alternative to fructone. A control reaction for the synthesis of EL-EG ketal was attempted at 1:1 molar ratio (6.94 mmol) of reactants, at 120 °C for 1 h, in absence of the catalyst. The experiment showed 5% conversion of EL with 100% selectivity of EL-EG ketal (Table 1 , entry 1). It is to be noted that the ketal formation reaction mechanism is reversible and happens in presence of the by-product (H2O), formed during the reaction. This necessitated continuous removal of H2O from the product mixture, which was carried out using Dean-Stark (DS) apparatus using cyclohexane solvent. The control reaction in DS method resulted 30% conversion of EL with 100% EL-EG ketal selectivity (Table 1, entry 2). Usually, ketal/acetal formation reactions are reported using Dean-Stark distillation (DS) for better conversion of the reactants to products [44,55–59]. To increase the conversion of reactants to obtain ketal, we used Na-β zeolite catalyst in presence and absence of DS (Table 1, entries 3 and 4). The Na-β zeolite showed 34% conversion in absence of DS, but interestingly, the catalytic activity doubled (68% conversion of EL) on applying of DS method for water removal. The H-form of β-zeolite (H-β) resulted in a similar conversion of EL like Na-β (Table 1, entry 5). According to TPD analysis, the acidic strength of H-β (0.45 mmol/g) is similar to Na-β zeolite (0.46 mmol/g). Thus, not much activity difference is to be expected when these catalysts are compared (Fig. 1 ). The number of Na+ cations is 1.3 wt.% in the Na-β zeolite, confirmed by SEM-EDX (Fig. S1A in the ESI). In H-β zeolite, the Na+ cations are less (0.24 wt%) (Fig. S1B in the ESI), which indicates that protonation has happened effectively during the conversion of Na-β to H-β. However, not much change in the overall acidity is observed supporting similar conversion of EL using both Na-β and H-β zeolites. Other acid catalysts including zeolites (Na-Y and Na-ZSM-5), resin (Amberlyst-15), and clay (Montmorillonite-MMT) were also screened for this reaction. The zeolite catalysts Na-Y and Na-ZSM-5 showed poor activity wherein the former showed no conversion while the latter showed only 9% conversion under similar conditions (Table 1, entries 6 and 7). The resin (Amberlyst-15) and clay (MMT) catalysts resulted in 57 and 45% conversion of EL with 98 and 100% selectivity of the desired ketal (Table 1, entries 8 and 9). The Na-Y and Na-ZSM-5 zeolites consists of weakly acidic sites (< 350 °C) (Fig. 1). The lack of strong acidic sites (which were observed in the case of Na-β, H-β, and MMT, 400–600 °C) in Na-Y and Na-ZSM-5 zeolites might be the reason for the lack of activity during ketal formation. The catalytic activity of screened catalysts could also be explained with the help of Py-FTIR and is depicted in Fig. 2 . The FTIR spectra were recorded after pyridine adsorption on the above-mentioned materials. The vibrations at 1445 and 1595 cm−1 are characteristic bands of Py adsorbed on Lewis acidic sites (L), while the 1545 cm−1 band is assigned to the pyridinum ion (PyH+) formed over Brӧnsted acidic sites (B) [60]. Absence or lesser number of these sites in Na-Y and Na-ZSM-5 zeolites correlated well with the poor activity exhibited, suggesting the necessity of acidic sites in enabling the reaction (Fig. 2a and 2b). The Py-FTIR of Amberlyst-15 and MMT proved the presence of high Brӧnsted acidic sites and few Lewis acidic sites, these catalysts showed moderate conversion of EL (Fig. 2f and 2g). β-zeolite exhibited both Brӧnsted and Lewis acidic sites (Fig. 2c). Na-Y and Na-ZSM-5 zeolites have weak acidic sites (confirmed by TPD; Fig. 1) and may not adsorb much pyridine, thus only a minimal amount of the Bronsted & Lewis acidic sites were observed (in Py-FTIR, Fig. 2) in these two cases. Poorer activity showed by Na-Y and Na-ZSM-5 compared to the control (Table 1, entries 2, 6 and 7) suggests a hindered interaction between the reactant molecules with these catalytic surfaces. To confirm this, reactions were conducted with inactive materials such as MgO (base) and alumina (neutral). EL remained unconverted in both these cases corroborating the above observation (Table 1, entries 10 and 11). The blank reaction showed 30% conversion of EL whereas materials such as Na-Y, Na-ZSM-5, MgO, and neutral alumina gave zero conversion or lesser conversion because of the hindered activation of the reactants on the catalysts surfaces as compared to the blank reaction (where under homogeneous mixing of the reactants, the interaction possibilities are higher) wherein these mentioned catalysts possessed basic, neutral or weakly acidic sites where the substrate interaction has to occur under heterogeneous reaction conditions. On the other hand, the reaction is accelerated via an activation of both the reagents (i.e., EL and EG) and catalysed by strong Lewis/Bronsted acidic catalysts. The interaction of both the reactants with the catalyst surface brings them in close proximity that enhances the rate of the reaction. However, catalysts like neutral alumina and MgO, such surface adsorption of both reactants molecules in close proximity are less favoured and thus poorer conversion results. According to SEM-EDX analysis (Fig. S1 in the ESI), the Na/Al ratio of Na-β zeolite is 0.5, it is 1 and 1.3 for Na-Y and Na-ZSM-5. The Na-Y zeolite has higher amount of Na+ ions (9.42 wt%) compared with Al sites (8.67 wt%). The oversaturation of Na+ ions in both zeolites (Na-Y and Na-ZSM-5) and the reduced availability of the Lewis acidic Al sites could be another reason for weak acidity and reduced activity towards the ketal formation reaction. Interestingly, instead of EL when we used levulinic acid (LA) as a reactant and conducted the reaction using Na-Y & Na-ZSM-5 zeolites (Table 1, entries 12 and 13), gave 32% & 45% conversion of LA with 30% & 43% yield of LA-EG ketal, while the esterified product observed was very less (2%) in both cases, which suggests that LA adsorb on the surfaces of Na-Y and Na-ZSM-5 along with polyol thereby facilitating the reaction. In the case of EL, this phenomenon presumably did not occur, which might be the reason for no or lesser activity of Na-Y, Na-ZSM-5, as well as other inactive or less active materials. Though the above explanations offered may provide some plausible thoughts for these unexpected results, we fail to clearly understand the actual reasons thereon, especially using Na-Y and Na-ZSM-5 zeolites. In addition, the higher activity of β-zeolite as compared to other screened catalysts could be attributed to its unique pore topology and the presence of local defects in their structures through octahedral extra-framework aluminium (AlO6) that generates Lewis acidic properties. The sufficient amount of Bronsted, as well as Lewis acidic sites in the β-zeolite, could be the reason for high activity towards the ketal formation as compared to other screened catalysts. Recently, we reported β-zeolite as the only active acid catalyst for the preparation of arylated γ-lactone from LA with aromatics. In this case Lewis acidic properties of β-zeolite played an important role in the reaction [61]. Na-β was chosen as the catalyst for EL-EG ketal preparation in presence of DS distillation owing to its superior activity. A comparison of the catalytic activity of Na-β with reported homogenous and heterogeneous catalysts for ketal formation with their yields using azeotropic distillation has been provided (Table S1 in the ESI). Various reaction parameters such as molar ratio of reactants, catalyst amount, reaction temperature and time were optimized to obtain maximum conversion of EL and high yield of the desired ketal. 3.2 Parameter variation for optimization of EL-EG ketal preparation using Na-β catalyst EL-EG ketal was the only product observed under our reaction conditions with Na-β catalyst, and also during parameter optimization reactions. Henceforth, we have mentioned the conversion of EL only and not the selectivity of EL-EG, upon the variation of reaction parameters. To maximize the conversion of EL-EG ketal, the molar ratio of the reactants were varied from 1 to 2.25, under the reaction conditions mentioned in Fig. 3 A and keeping the amount of EL (1 g: 6.94 mmol) constant. An increase in the conversion of EL was observed by increasing the molar ratio of EG, i.e., 1, 1.5, and 2 molar ratio showing 68, 90 and 99% conversion of EL. Further increase to 2.25 molar ratio of EG also showed the same conversion of EL (99%). Hence, EL and EG molar ratio was fixed at 1:2 for further parameter optimization studies. Actually, the ketal formation reaction stoichiometry is 1:1, but at this ratio the conversion of EL remained incomplete under our experimental conditions while the reaction kinetics was favoured on increasing the ratio. Further, when we analyzed the by-product water collected by the Dean-Stark distillation method using GC diluting with acetone, we observed some EG (15–20%) in it, indicating that the polyol is miscible in water. Thus, some amount of polyol is lost during Dean Stark distillation. Thus, an extra amount of polyol is required for this conversion. EL was not observed in water (during GC analysis), and thus additional polyol was required to ensure a complete conversion of EL. We optimized EL:polyol ratio to 1:2, which ensured the complete conversion of EL. Further, the reaction time was varied from 30 to 120 min by a factor of 30 min at 1 (EL):2 (EG) molar ratio, 10 wt% of Na-β catalyst w.r.t. EL (100 mg) at 120 °C. After 30 min reaction, 82% conversion of EL was obtained and it reached to 99% in 1 h and further increment of the reaction time (1.5 h) did not show any significant change in the conversion. Thus, 1 h reaction time was fixed for further studies (Fig. 3B). At optimised molar ratio 1 (EL): 2 (EG) and reaction time (1 h), the catalyst loading (wt% w.r.t. EL) was varied from 5 to 15 wt% (stepwise increment of 2.5 wt%). An increase in the conversion of EL was observed with an increment in catalyst loading up to 10 wt%. Further increment to 12.5 and 15 wt% catalyst also resulted in similar conversion of EL as compared to 10 wt% of catalyst (Fig. 3C). The 5 wt% (50 mg), 7.5 wt% (75 mg), and 10 wt% (100 mg) catalyst resulted in 82, 94 and 99% conversion of EL, and thus we selected 10 wt% (100 mg) of Na-β catalyst as the optimum catalyst amount for further studies. We studied the effect of temperature towards the reaction at optimized 1 (EL): 2 (EG) molar ratio, reaction time (1 h), and catalyst 10 wt%. The reaction temperature was varied from 80 to 140 °C with an increment of 20 °C. A gradual increase in the conversion of EL was observed on increasing the temperature up to 120 °C. Further increment to 140 °C yielded similar conversion of EL as 120 °C (Fig. 3D). The temperature 80, 100, and 120 °C showed 43, 86, and 99% conversion of EL. After variation of all parameters for the conversion of EL with EG to EL-EG ketal, the final optimization condition for the formation of bio-based ketals was molar ratio of EL: EG is 1:2 reaction time (1 h), 10 wt% of Na-β zeolite catalyst (100 mg) and temperature (120 °C) (Table 2 , entry 1). We have also attempted the preparation of ethyl levulinate-glycerol (EL-Gly) ketal from EL with glycerol (Gly) under our optimized reaction conditions. The reaction showed 60% conversion of EL with 100% selectivity of EL-Gly-ketal with 55:45 ratio of 1,2: 1,3 EL-Gly-ketal products. The ratio remained almost constant (a variation of ± 3) during reaction parameter optimization studies, and hence mixture of these isomeric products are mentioned as 100% selectivity of EL-Gly-ketal. In this study also, we mentioned only the conversion of EL, as in the previous case and 100% selectivity of the two products (1,2/1,3 EL-Gly-ketal) was observed. A decrease in the conversion of EL was observed for the preparation of EL-Gly-ketals as compared to the preparation EL-EG ketal. This could be attributed to the bigger size of Gly-and associated steric effect. We have studied the effects of various reaction parameters for maximizing the conversion of EL with Gly, as well. 3.3 Parameter variation for optimization of EL-Gly-ketal preparation using Na-β catalyst For the optimization of the synthesis of EL-Gly-ketal, initially the reaction time variation was conducted from 1 to 4 h by a factor of 1 h at 1 (EL):2 (Gly) molar ratio of reactants, 120 °C and 10 wt% of Na-β (100 mg). In this study, we observed that on increasing the reaction time from 1 to 4 h the conversion of EL increased (Fig. 4 A). 1, 2, 3 and 4 h reaction time showed 60, 86, 92 and 98% conversion of EL, and thus 4 h reaction time was fixed for further studies using Gly. Fixing the molar ratio of EL:Gly-to 1:2 and the reaction time (4 h), we varied the catalyst amount (wt% ratio w.r.t. EL) from 5 to 15 wt% by the variation of 5 wt%. Increase in the conversion of EL was noted upon increasing the catalyst amount up to 10 wt%; a further increase to 15 wt% catalyst failed to increase the conversion beyond 98%. The 5 wt% (50 mg) and 10 wt% (100 mg) catalyst loading resulted in 94 and 98% conversion of EL (Fig. 4B). Thus, 10 wt% (100 mg) of Na-β catalyst was selected for further studies. The effect of temperature towards the reaction was also studied at a molar ratio 1 (EL):2 (Gly), reaction time (4 h), and 10 wt% of catalyst (100 mg). The reaction temperature was varied from 80 to 140 °C by an increment of 20 °C and it was observed that increasing the reaction temperature gradually increased the conversion of EL. The reactions carried out at temperatures 80, 100, 120 and 140 °C showed 50, 94, 98 and 100% conversions of EL (Fig. 4C). In addition, the effect of the molar ratio of the reactants (EL with Gly) on the reaction was carried out with 10 wt% (100 mg) of Na-β zeolite catalyst at 140 °C for 4 h. Increasing the molar ratio of glycerol to EL, we observed an increase in the conversion of EL. The glycerol molar ratio 1, 1.5, and 2 to EL resulted in 87, 98 and 100% conversion of EL (Fig. 4D). After a variation of all parameters for the conversion of EL with Gly-to EL-Gly-ketal, the final optimized condition was molar ratio of EL: Gly 1:2, reaction time 4 h, catalyst 10 wt% (100 mg) of Na-β zeolite and temperature 140 °C (Table 2, entry 2). 3.4 Substrate scope for preparation of ketal intermediates We explored the reaction scope for the preparation of ketals using various biomass-based substrates under our catalytic conditions. Ketones ranging from LA and its esters (methyl levulinate and butyl levulinate), 2-butanone, 5-nonanone, and cyclohexanone and polyols such as 1,3-propanediol, 1,2-propanediol, 1,4-butanediol, and 1,6-hexanediol were employed. We also attempted acetal preparation using octanal with EG under the same reaction conditions. The results of these reactions are discussed below. 3.4.1 LA and its esters substrate variation study Methyl and butyl levulinate in presence of EG showed 98 and 97% conversion with 100% selectivity of EG-ketal product (Table 2, entries 3 and 5). These levulinate esters in presence of Gly-also resulted in good conversion; methyl levulinate (98%) and butyl levulinate (98%) with 100% combined selectivity of ketal products (1,2/1,3 Gly-ketal) (Table 2, entries 4 and 6). All the three levulinic esters studied, i.e., methyl, ethyl, and butyl levulinate gave similar results for the formation of EG and Gly-ketals products (Table 2, entries 1–6). Further, we studied LA as the reactant with EG under the same reaction conditions (mentioned in the Table 2). Here we observed 99% conversion of LA with 87% selectivity of the desired ketal. The carboxylic functional group of LA was also found to be active for esterification with EG under acidic reaction conditions. Thus, we observed side products such as ester [2-hydroxyethyl 4-oxopentanoate], and combination of keto-ester [2-hydroxyethyl 3-(2-methyl-1,3-dioxolan-2-yl)propanoate] in smaller yields, ester (3%), keto-ester (8%), and other unidentified products (2%) (Table 2, entry 7). 3.4.2 Variation of the polyols Several polyols were employed in presence of EL to check for the utility of our reaction conditions for the synthesis of a basket of ketals (Table 3 ). Both 1,2 and 1,3 propanediol resulted in a good conversion of EL (98 and 96%) with 99% selectivity of corresponding 1,2 and 1,3-ketal products (Table 3, entries 1 and 2). Further, 1,4-butanediol resulted in 84% conversion of EL with 100% selectivity of 1,4- ketal (Table 3, entry 3). The decrease in conversion of EL using 1,4-butanediol as the reactant may be due to the stability of the obtained ketal product. According to Baeyer's angle strain theory, five and six membered rings are more stable than smaller or larger rings. 1,2 and 1,3 diols form stable 5 and 6 membered rings of ketals while using 1,4-diol forms 7 membered ring which is less stable and thus the formation of this product is comparatively less favoured than 5 and 6 membered ring ketals. Moreover, in presence of 1,6-hexanediol, we noticed no conversion of EL and no significant observation of 1,6-ketal (Table 3, entry 4). This could also be rationalized from the angle strain theory and support our previous observation with 1,4-butanediol. 3.4.3 Carbonyl compounds variation The reaction scope was further explored by employing various carbonyl compounds including ketones such as (2-octanone, 5-nonanone, and cyclohexanone), and aldehyde such as octanal. These experiments were carried out using EG as polyol (Table 4 ). 2-octanone, 5-nonanone, and cyclohexanone resulted 100, 99, and 98% selectivity of desired ketal with 95, 70, and 100% conversion of these ketones (Table 4, entries 1–3). The conversion of 5-nonanone was the least in this series and may be due to the bulkiness of the reactant; the reactive group (keto carbon) is placed in-between two butane chains that can undergo CC single bond rotation and effectively shield the CO group, thereby hindering the reaction. Thus the interaction of the substrate with the active sites of catalyst is reduced. The reaction scope was further broadened by the preparation of acetal using aldehyde. The octanal, used as the model aldehyde, showed 99% conversion with 99% selectivity of acetal with EG as polyol reactant (Table 4, entry 4). 3.5 Recyclability studies of Na-β zeolite catalyst Recyclability of a catalyst is beneficial for industrial applications, as it helps in reducing the cost of the process. The used catalyst (Na-β) was washed with acetone (twice) and dried at 100 °C for 3 h. This oven dried catalyst (termed UNa-β) was reused under the same reaction conditions for the preparation of EL-EG ketal, and showed a decrease in the conversion of EL from 99 to 82% without any loss in the selectivity of the ketal product (Fig. 5 , cycles 1 and 2). The decrease in the catalytic activity is attributed to the formation of organic carbon moiety during the reaction that blocked the acidic sites of catalyst, thereby decreasing the catalytic activity. A detailed study on organic carbon deposition on β-zeolite during the reaction and its characterization using various physiochemical techniques (FT-IR, CHNS, Surface area, SEM, TEM, CP-MAS NMR, and Py-FTIR) is discussed in catalyst characterization section. The used catalyst (UNa-β) was calcined at 350 °C for 3 h in an endeavour to remove the adhered organic carbon. After calcination, the catalyst labelled as UNa-βC, showed similar reactivity for the synthesis of ketal as that of fresh Na-β catalyst, rendering similar conversion of EL and selectivity of the EL-EG ketal for several reaction cycles (Fig. 5, cycles 3–5). 3.6 Product confirmation using 13C NMR Critical analysis of the product is necessary in the present work, as multiple product formation is associated with this synthetic protocol. Along with levulinic-ketal products, there are possibilities for the formation of other products as well (Fig. 6 ) [55]. Presence of levulinates and polyols in a reaction medium with an acid catalyst, gives rise to a possibility for the formation of trans-esterified product such as 2-hydroxyethyl 4-oxopentanoate (considering EL with EG reactants). The trans-esterified product is a functional isomer of the desired product (ketal) and have similar molecular weights. The second competitive reaction is hydrolysis, as water is formed as the by-product during the preparation of ketals. H2O thus formed can hydrolyse the levulinate to form LA and alcohols. Thus, for monitoring the present reaction, 13C NMR is the best and reliable tool for identifying the structural characteristics of the obtained products in unravelling the information on the carbon environment, necessary to distinguish ketal or trans-esterified and/or hydrolysed product (LA). No hydrolysis product, i.e., LA was observed during the conversion of EL with polyols and hence no esterification product was identified (Tables 1 and 2). The carbonyl oxygen in alkyl levulinates has more electron density as compared with carboxylic oxygen. According to literature, high acidic strength (p-Toluenesulfonic acid), higher amount of acid catalyst, prolonged reaction time (> 4 h), and increased amount of polyols to levuli(nate/acid) molar ratio (10:1) are conducive to ester and kero-ester formation with moderate selectivity [44,55,56]. Our experimental conditions are milder compared to the literature reports, supporting the absence of hydrolysis and trans-esterified products in our case. The keto carbon of EL showed a peak at δ 206 ppm. After the reaction, the obtained product mixture did not show any peak at δ 206 ppm, corroborating a complete conversion of keto functionality of EL. In the product mixture corresponding to the EL-EG ketal mentioned in Table 2, entry 1, the 13C NMR spectrum showed a new peak at δ 108.9 ppm which corresponds to the obtained ketal carbon (Fig. 7 ). The keto carbon of EL during the reaction with EG is converted to quaternary carbon of EL-EG ketal. The same observation is identified in EL-Gly-ketal (product mixture of Table 2, entry 2) but here we observed two peaks corresponding to 1,2-EL-Gly-ketal and 1,3-EL-Gly-ketal. The δ 109.6 and δ 109.3 ppm indicate 1,2 and 1,3 EL-Gly-quaternary ketal carbons; the δ 173.3 and δ 173.2 ppm indicate 1,2 and 1,3 EL-Gly-ester carbons of ketal product respectively, which are clearly shown in Fig. 8 . Gratifyingly, 13C NMR spectrum did not show any carbon moiety reminiscent of the trans-esterified and LA side products which means the catalytic system does not undergo trans-esterification and/or hydrolysis side reactions. The other products obtained while exploring the substrate scope of the system were also confirmed by similar protocol (using 13C NMR) and are mentioned in the Fig. S2-S14 (see ESI). 3.7 Catalyst characterization The decrease in the catalytic activity of the used catalyst (here UNa-β) is due to the formation of organic carbon during the reaction. The characteristic of organic carbon deposition in used β-zeolite sample (UNa-β) is studied using various analytical tools such as PXRD, FT-IR, CHNS, CP-MAS NMR (27Al and 29Si), SEM, TEM, and surface area measurements. The crystallinity of the catalysts after different cycles, i.e., Na-β, UNa-β, and UNa-βC at various cycles (2nd, 3rd, and 5th) remain unaffected. In all cases, the intensity and the patterns of diffraction profiles are similar (Fig. S15 in the ESI). The FT-IR of UNa-β showed extra bands as compared with fresh Na-β zeolite in the region of 1500–2000 and 3000–2800 cm−1 that disappeared on calcination in air (referred to as UNa-βC) (see Fig. 9 ). The FT-IR revealed that, the deposited organic carbon in UNa-β zeolite may consist of carbonyl/carboxy derivatives along with alkyl (sp3; CH) moiety. The Py-FTIR (Fig. 2), showed band at 1445 cm−1 for fresh Na-β catalyst indicating the presence of Lewis-acidic sites which are active for the reaction (Fig. 2c). This band, however, decreased for the used catalyst (UNa-β) and reappeared for the calcined catalyst (UH-β) augmenting the relationship between Lewis acidity and catalytic activity (Fig. 2d and 2e). Thus, the removal of deposited organic carbon moieties that adhere over Lewis acidic sites upon calcination restores the acidic sites. The organic carbon deposition in the used catalyst (UNa-β) has also been confirmed by an increase in carbon content measured by CHNS. The analysis of the catalysts (Table 5 ) showed an increase to about 3.2% carbon in UNa-β from 0.6% in Na-β, and that decreased to 0.6% for UNa-βC. The textural properties (surface area, pore size, and pore volume) of catalysts are summarized in Table 5. The BET surface area of the Na-β was measured as 483 m²/g with pore volume 0.33 cm3/g. A decrease in the surface area (339 m2/g) and pore volume (0.29 cm3/g) of the used catalyst (UNa-β), was observed, which supported that organic carbon moiety presumably blocked the pores resulting in the decreased surface area and pores. After calcination, a restoration of surface area (516 m²/g) as well as pore volume (0.32 cm3/g) was observed for UNa-βC during calcination, concomitant to the removal of the organic moiety from the zeolite. The same observation was found in micropore surface analysis as well. The micropore volume and micropore surface area for the catalyst samples were measured using the t-plot method. The UNa-β showed an approximate 53% decrease in micropore surface area (183 m2/g from 344 m2/g) and micropore volume (0.095 cm3/g from 0.179 cm3/g) due to the coke formation and pore blockage during the reaction. However, the used sample after calcination showed the surface area and micropore volume similar to the pristine catalyst sample (Table S2 in the ESI). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the all zeolite catalysts (Na-β, UNa-β, and UNa-βC) showed characteristic type-IV isotherm which was attributed to the capillary condensation of pores with H1-type hysteresis according to IUPAC classification, and the pore size indicated a mesoporosity (Fig. 10 ). Pore diameter was maintained in all three catalysts with slight changes (3.9 nm for Na-β, 4.1 for UNa-β, and 3.8 for UNa-βC) (Table 5 and Fig. 11 ). The scanning electron microscopic (SEM) analysis of Na-β, UNa-β and UNa-βC are shown in Fig. 12 . The catalyst (Na-β) depicted spherical morphology with regular arrangement. On the contrary, UNa-β catalyst showed the deposition of organic carbon moieties in some areas. In view of this, reactant molecules possibly faced a diffusion limitation towards the active acidic sites of the zeolite and thus causes a decrease in the catalytic activity. However, in the calcined catalyst (UNa-βC) removal of the organic carbon of the used catalyst was observed and showed similar catalytic activity like fresh catalyst (Na-β), and the initial activity was restored. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM) provides insight into the local structure of crystalline phases. The TEM analysis revealed that the catalysts (Na-β and UNa-β) had well-organized ordered porous surface with average particles sizes between 20 and 35 nm. The TEM images of catalysts are mentioned in the Fig. 13 . The organic carbon moieties in used Na-β zeolite (UNa-β) was not observed in the TEM images, which could be due to the fact that high electron beam of TEM burns and removes the organic carbon. Solid state NMR is an important tool to predict the structural changes in zeolite as a consequence of the catalytic reactions. The 27Al and 29Si NMR CP-MAS NMR of all three catalysts (Na-β, UNa-β, and UNa-βC) were studied. The 27Al CP-MAS NMR of catalysts given in Fig. 14 , showed primarily two peaks. The major peak approximately in the range of 53–55 δ ppm was attributed to 4-coordinated tetrahedral framework of aluminium (AlO4) species and minor peak in range of 0.14–0.58 δ ppm correspond to octahedral extra-framework aluminium (AlO6). On comparing Na-β and UNa-βC, the octahedral aluminium peak of UNa-β zeolite showed broadening, indicating a structural distortion in the AlO6 framework of the zeolite due to interaction of deposited organic carbon moiety. The AlO6 is responsible for the Lewis acidic sites in the β-zeolite and thus relevant to the reaction described in this work. In the case of used zeolite (UNa-β), the formed organic moiety blocked/modified the extra-framework Lewis acidic sites of AlO6, resulting in the observed suppression of the catalytic activity. The reactivated catalyst (UNa-βC) obtained upon calcination showed a sharp peak which is similar to the fresh β-zeolite, suggesting the restoration of the catalyst structure. The 29Si CP-MAS NMR of catalysts are presented in Fig. S16 (see ESI). The 29Si NMR of all three catalysts (Na-β, UNa-β, and UNa-βC) appeared at −110 δ ppm which corresponds to framework Si in a Si(SiO)4 environment in the zeolite matrices. The deposited organic carbon moiety in the UNa-β zeolite does not affect the Si atom unlike Al, thus the chemical shift value of Si peak remains unchanged in the used catalyst. 3.8 Reaction mechanism The mechanism for the formation of EL-EG ketal is given in Fig. 15 . Initially, the lone pair of electrons on the keto group of EL interacts with acidic sites of the catalyst. Such interaction develops a partial positive charge on keto/activated carbon that promotes a nucleophilic attack via one of the oxygen lone pairs of EG resulting in the formation of a hemiketal intermediate. This intermediate is known as the tetrahedral carbonyl addition intermediate; here it is ethyl 4,6-dihydroxy-4-methylhexanoate. Further, the formed hydroxyl group of intermediate (hemiacetal) interacts with acidic sites of catalyst and hydroxyl carbon gets a partial positive charge. This charge is finally neutralized by the lone pair of oxygen of hydroxyethoxy moiety through cyclization to form the desired ketal product with the removal of H2O molecule. Thus, a continuous removal of the by-product H2O helps in driving the reaction in the forward direction, ensuring the selective formation of the desired ketals. Both Lewis and Bronsted acidic sites were active for the reaction. Because of the Bronsted acidic sites in MMT and Amberlyst-15, mixture (Bronsted & Lewis) of acidic sites in β-zeolite, good conversion of EL was observed. The reaction of levulinic esters with polyols forming ketal is more favourable than the trans-esterification reaction. This can be rationalized as the carbonyl oxygen in alkyl levulinates has more electron density as compared with carboxylic oxygen. Thus, the acidic sites in the catalyst (vacant orbital of Lewis acid or H + of Bronsted acid) interact with carbonyl oxygen lone pair (instead of carboxylic oxygen) as per the mechanism mentioned in Fig. 15, which favours the ketal formation. 3.9 Reaction with crude glycerol (biodiesel co-product) Glycerol obtained from bio-diesel production using solid base catalyst such as Layered Double Hydroxide (CaAl2-LDH) is used for the ketal preparation. The glycerol synthesis followed similar procedure used in the literature, as a by-product of the transesterification of sunflower oil [62]. The glycerol is ∼ 90% pure and water is the remaining major constituent of the mixture. The water is removed by azeotropic distillation (Dean-Stark setup) using cyclohexane solvent, resulting in 98% pure glycerol and which has been used for ketal preparation. The reaction with biodiesel derived glycerol (98% purity) and EL was conducted at our optimized reaction conditions (Table 2, entry 2) using Na-β catalyst and 95% selectivity of ketal product with 98% conversion of EL was observed in this case. We believe that the synthetic protocol will be helpful to the biodiesel as well LA producer industries, by ensuring a value addition of crude glycerol by-product. 4 Conclusions We have successfully demonstrated a sustainable process for the synthesis of ketals using a recyclable heterogeneous Na-β zeolite catalyst employing biomass-based ketones and polyols as reactants. The azeotropic distillation using Dean-Stark method played a crucial role wherein continuous removal of by-product water improved the conversion of reactants and ensured product selectivity. Reaction parameters were optimized for ethyl levulinate-ethylene glycol ketal (EL-EG ketal) and ethyl levulinate-glycerol ketal (EL-Gly-ketal) from ethyl levulinate with ethylene glycol and glycerol respectively that rendered high yields of ketals (99% EL-EG and 100% for EL-Gly). Formation of ketal product was confirmed by 13C NMR which unambiguously supported the presence of quaternary carbon (δ 108–110 ppm) of the ketal product. Various ketones and polyols have been successfully employed for the preparation of ketals under the optimized reaction conditions to demonstrate the broad reaction scope and to attest the generality of the protocol. In most cases, high conversion of reactant and selectivity of the desired product were observed. Though the as-used catalyst showed lesser activity, it was reactivated by simple calcination and was successfully reused for five subsequent cycles without any loss in its activity, similar to that of fresh Na-β zeolite catalyst. Adhered organic carbon moiety on the catalyst (UH-β) surface was implicated for the catalyst deactivation which was characterized by various physicochemical techniques. 97% yield of EL-Gly-ketal with 98% EL conversion was noted even using crude glycerol (biodiesel co-product), emphasizing the advantage of our protocol for value addition to the bio-diesel industries. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, we demonstrate the preparation of ketals from biomass-based carbonyl compounds and polyols. Our emphasis is on levulinate-based ketals using ethyl levulinate (EL) with ethylene glycol (EG) or glycerol (Gly) as polyols. Among the catalysts screened, Na-β zeolite resulted in 99% conversion of EL with 100% selectivity for the corresponding ketal within 1 h, when used in conjunction with azeotropic distillation in cyclohexane medium. Using Gly-as the polyol, a similar yield and selectivity was obtained, albeit after a longer reaction time (4 h). We have explored the reaction scope by using a multitude of biomass-based ketones and polyols as reactants, which showed excellent selectivity for the ketals. Slight deactivation of the catalyst was observed after reaction, owing to the deposition of organic carbon on the catalyst, which was identified using analytical tools. The deactivated catalyst was regenerated on calcination. This strategy was successfully demonstrated for ketal preparation using crude glycerol with EL.
coredata.dc:title: Selective preparation of renewable ketals from biomass-based carbonyl compounds with polyols using β-zeolite catalyst
